Post.title: How to change icons in AstroNvim on Ubuntu
Post._content: If you are new to [AstroNvim](https://github.com/AstroNvim/AstroNvim), and haven't installed any fonts on you linux, the default icons in AstroNvim might not be recongnized. ## Install Nerd Fonts on Linux Choose the font you like (I choose DejaVuSansMono), download it on [Nerd Fonts](https://www.nerdfonts.com/font-downloads) and unzip the compressed file. Then, install the fonts on linux: ```bash unzip DejaVuSansMono.zip cp -r DejaVuSansMono/* ~/.local/share/fonts/ ``` Update the font-cache: ``` fc-cache -fv ``` Change the fonts for terminal: ## Change Config File in Nvim Go to nvim config directory: ```bash cd ~/.config/nvim/user ``` Change `icons_enabled` to `true` in the `init.lua` file: ```lua return { options = { g = { icons_enabled = true, }, }, } ``` Since nerd fonts is installed, the icons should be working right now. See the official [Doc](https://astronvim.com/Recipes/icons) for more details.
Post.raw: --- title: How to change icons in AstroNvim on Ubuntu date: 2023-04-16 15:28:25 tags: nvim --- If you are new to [AstroNvim](https://github.com/AstroNvim/AstroNvim), and haven't installed any fonts on you linux, the default icons in AstroNvim might not be recongnized. ## Install Nerd Fonts on Linux Choose the font you like (I choose DejaVuSansMono), download it on [Nerd Fonts](https://www.nerdfonts.com/font-downloads) and unzip the compressed file. Then, install the fonts on linux: ```bash unzip DejaVuSansMono.zip cp -r DejaVuSansMono/* ~/.local/share/fonts/ ``` Update the font-cache: ``` fc-cache -fv ``` Change the fonts for terminal: ## Change Config File in Nvim Go to nvim config directory: ```bash cd ~/.config/nvim/user ``` Change `icons_enabled` to `true` in the `init.lua` file: ```lua return { options = { g = { icons_enabled = true, }, }, } ``` Since nerd fonts is installed, the icons should be working right now. See the official [Doc](https://astronvim.com/Recipes/icons) for more details.

Install Nerd Fonts on Linux

Choose the font you like (I choose DejaVuSansMono), download it on Nerd Fonts and unzip the compressed file.

Then, install the fonts on linux:

Update the font-cache:

Change the fonts for terminal:

Change Config File in Nvim

Go to nvim config directory:

Change icons_enabled to true in the init.lua file:

Since nerd fonts is installed, the icons should be working right now.

See the official Doc for more details.

Update the font-cache:

Go to nvim config directory:

Change icons_enabled to true in the init.lua file:

Since nerd fonts is installed, the icons should be working right now.

See the official Doc for more details.

Post.title: Simple Bank, Lecture 07 - DB Trasaction Lock
Post._content:
```sql
-- name: GetAccount :one
SELECT * FROM accounts
WHERE id = $1 LIMIT 1;
```



- **FOR UPDATE**
    - transaction(select) account
    - accountselect, blockselect account, account
    - FOR UPDATE: blockquery
        - query selectupdate, sqlblock

- FOR **NO KEY** UPDATE
    - primary keyupdate
    - dbprimary keyblockquery

```sql
-- name: GetAccountForUpdate :one
SELECT * FROM accounts
WHERE id = $1 LIMIT 1
FOR NO KEY UPDATE;
```
Post.raw:

title: Simple Bank, Lecture 07 - DB Trasaction Lock

tags: simple-bank, backend
---

```sql
-- name: GetAccount :one
SELECT * FROM accounts
WHERE id = $1 LIMIT 1;
```



- **FOR UPDATE**
    - transaction(select) account
    - accountselect, blockselect account, account
    - FOR UPDATE: blockquery
        - query selectupdate, sqlblock

- FOR **NO KEY** UPDATE
    - primary keyupdate
    - dbprimary keyblockquery

```sql
-- name: GetAccountForUpdate :one
SELECT * FROM accounts
WHERE id = $1 LIMIT 1
FOR NO KEY UPDATE;
```
Post.content:
• FOR UPDATE

    • transaction(select) account
    • accountselect, blockselect account, account
    • FOR UPDATE: blockquery
      • query selectupdate, sqlblock

  • FOR NO KEY UPDATE

    • primary keyupdate
    • dbprimary keyblockquery

• FOR UPDATE

    • transaction(select) account
    • accountselect, blockselect account, account
    • FOR UPDATE: blockquery
      • query selectupdate, sqlblock

  • FOR NO KEY UPDATE

    • primary keyupdate
    • dbprimary keyblockquery

Post.title: Simple Bank, Lecture 08 - Avoid Deadlock
Post._content:
avoid:

- transaction 1:
    - update id 1
    - update id 2
- transaction 2:
    - update id 2
    - update id 1

**deadlock**!!

change to:

- transaction 1:
    - update id 1
    - update id 2
- transaction 2:
    - update id 1
    - update id 2

orderid (

Post.title: Simple Bank, Lecture 09 - Isolation Level
Post._content:
A database transaction should follow the **ACID** property:

- Atomicity
    - operation, transaction faildb
- Isolation
    - Concurrent transactions
- Consistency
    - transaction, db statevalid
- Durability
    - data written by a successful transaction must be recorded in persistent storage

,  **Read Phenomena**  Isolation property:

- Dirty Read
    - transactiontransaction uncommitteddata
- Non-repeatable Read
    - transactiondatadata(by another **committed** transaction)
- Phantom() Read
    - transactionrows (due to another recently **committed** transaction)
- serialization anomaly
    - transaction sequentially run, 

4 Standard **Isolation Levels** are defined by ANSI:

- Read uncommitted
    - commitdata
- Read Committed
    - commitdata (avoid dirty read)
- Repeatable read
    - select query (avoid non-repeatable & phantom read)
- serializable
    - seriallytransaction, concurrently

(MySQL)

| Isolation Level | Dirty Read | Non-repeatable Read | Phantom Read | Serialization Anomaly |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Read Uncommitted | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| Read Committed | No | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| Repeatable Read | No | No | No | Yes |
| Serializable | No | No | No | No |

(PostgreSQL)

| Isolation Level | Dirty Read | Non-repeatable Read | Phantom Read | Serialization Anomaly |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Read Uncommitted | No | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| Read Committed | No | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| Repeatable Read | No | No | No | Yes |
| Serializable | No | No | No | No |

MySQL v.s. PostgreSQL

- MySQLtransactionisolation level, PostgreSQLtransactionisolation level
- MySQL
    - serializable, mysql SELECT  SELECT FOR SHARE
        - transaction 1 SELECT * from accounts where id = 1, transaction 2update account id 1block
        
        ```sql
        T1:
        	select * from accounts where id = 1;
        T2:
        
        ---
        T1:
        
        T2:
        	update account set balance = balance - 10 where id = 1; 
        ---
        
        Transaction 2 would be blocked
        ```
        
        ```sql
        T1:
        	select * from accounts where id = 1;
        T2:
        
        ---
        T1:
        
        T2:
        	update account set balance = balance - 10 where id = 1;
        ---
        T1:
        	update account set balance = balance - 10 where id = 1;
        T2:
        
        ---
        
        Dead lock would occur, since T2 is waiting T1 to release the lock, 
        while T1 is also waiting to T2
        ```
        
- PostgreSQL
    - read uncommitted  read committed 
        - read uncommitted  dirty read
    - repeatable read  phantom read
- serializable level serialization anomaly 
    - PostgreSQL: dependency check, querytransaction, error
        
        ```sql
        T1:
        	select sum(balance) from accounts; 
        T2:
        
        ---
        
        T1:
        	insert into accounts(owner, balance, currency) values ('sum', 810, 'USD')
        T2:
        
        ---
        
        T1:
        
        T2:
        	insert into accounts(owner, balance, currency) values ('sum', 810, 'USD')
        ---
        
        T1:
        	commit; #success
        T2:
        
        ---
        
        T1:
        
        T2:
        	commit; #fail
        ---
        
        T2 would fail to commit. 
        Since the same insert query has been queried by T2.
        ```
        
    - MySQL: locking mechanism,  share locktransactiondata

Retry Mechanism

- There might be errors, timeout or deadlocks

[https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-transaction-isolation-levels.html](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-transaction-isolation-levels.html)

[https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/transaction-iso.html](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/transaction-iso.html)

- serializable level serialization anomaly

        ```sql
        ---

        Since the same insert query has been queried by T2.
        ```
        
    - MySQL: locking mechanism,  share locktransactiondata

Retry Mechanism

- There might be errors, timeout or deadlocks

[https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-transaction-isolation-levels.html](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-transaction-isolation-levels.html)

A database transaction should follow the ACID property:

  • Atomicity
    • operation, transaction faildb
  • Isolation
    • Concurrent transactions
  • Consistency
    • transaction, db statevalid
  • Durability
    • data written by a successful transaction must be recorded in persistent storage

, Read Phenomena Isolation property:

  • Dirty Read
    • transactiontransaction uncommitteddata
  • Non-repeatable Read
    • transactiondatadata(by another committed transaction)
  • Phantom() Read
    • transactionrows (due to another recently committed transaction)
  • serialization anomaly
    • transaction sequentially run,

4 Standard Isolation Levels are defined by ANSI:

  • Read uncommitted
    • commitdata
  • Read Committed
    • commitdata (avoid dirty read)
  • Repeatable read
    • select query (avoid non-repeatable & phantom read)
  • serializable
    • seriallytransaction, concurrently

(MySQL)

Isolation Level Dirty Read Non-repeatable Read Phantom Read Serialization Anomaly
Read Uncommitted Yes Yes Yes Yes
Read Committed No Yes Yes Yes
Repeatable Read No No No Yes
Serializable No No No No

(PostgreSQL)

Isolation Level Dirty Read Non-repeatable Read Phantom Read Serialization Anomaly
Read Uncommitted No Yes Yes Yes
Read Committed No Yes Yes Yes
Repeatable Read No No No Yes
Serializable No No No No

MySQL v.s. PostgreSQL

  • MySQLtransactionisolation level, PostgreSQLtransactionisolation level

  • MySQL

    • serializable, mysql SELECT SELECT FOR SHARE

      • transaction 1 SELECT * from accounts where id = 1, transaction 2update account id 1block

  • PostgreSQL

    • read uncommitted read committed
      • read uncommitted dirty read
    • repeatable read phantom read

  • serializable level serialization anomaly

    • PostgreSQL: dependency check, querytransaction, error

    • MySQL: locking mechanism, share locktransactiondata

Retry Mechanism

  • There might be errors, timeout or deadlocks

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/transaction-iso.html

Post.title: Simple Bank, Lecture 11 - RESTful API with GIN
Post._content:
RESTful API:

- RESTAPI
- HTTPREST
- Client-Server
- Stateless
- Cache
- Uniform Interface
- Layered System
- Code-On-Demand

HTTP Request Method

- GET), 
    - Read
- POST
    - Create
- PUT()
    - Update
- DELETE
    - Delete

main.go

- postgreSQL, 8080portrequest

server.go

- requestGINrouterhandler

account.go

- requesthandler (account, POST  createAccount, GET  getAccount / listAccount)
- account.sql.gofunctiondatadatabase

Post.title: Hello World
Post._content:
Welcome to [Hexo](https://hexo.io/)! This is your very first post. Check [documentation](https://hexo.io/docs/) for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in [troubleshooting](https://hexo.io/docs/troubleshooting.html) or you can ask me on [GitHub](https://github.com/hexojs/hexo/issues).

## Quick Start

### Create a new post

``` bash
$ hexo new "My New Post"
```

More info: [Writing](https://hexo.io/docs/writing.html)

### Run server

``` bash
$ hexo server
```

More info: [Server](https://hexo.io/docs/server.html)

### Generate static files

``` bash
$ hexo generate
```

More info: [Generating](https://hexo.io/docs/generating.html)

### Deploy to remote sites

``` bash
$ hexo deploy
```

More info: [Deployment](https://hexo.io/docs/one-command-deployment.html)
